title: Mayor of Mogadishu
text:
The Mayor of Mogadishu is head of the executive branch of <a href="Mogadishu">Mogadishu</a>, the <a href="Capital%20city">capital</a> of <a href="Somalia">Somalia</a>. The <a href="mayor">mayor</a>'s office administers all city services, public property, police and fire protection, most public agencies, and enforces laws within the city. The current mayor is <a href="Omar%20Muhamoud%20Finnish">Omar Muhamoud Finnish</a>, who was appointed on 22 August 2019 and succeeded the Martyr Mayor <a href="Abdirahman%20Omar%20Osman">Abdirahman Omar Osman</a>, who was killed on 1 August 2019 due to a suicide bombing occurred 24 July 2019 inside the mayor's office.
The mayor's office is located in <a href="Mogadishu%20City%20Hall">Mogadishu City Hall</a>, which was recently renovated after years of abandonment and decay during the <a href="Somali%20Civil%20War">Somali Civil War</a>. The mayor is not elected, but is appointed by the <a href="President%20of%20Somalia">President of Somalia</a>. The mayor also holds the title of Governor of <a href="Banaadir">Benaadir</a>, an administrative region whose territory is coextensive with the city of Mogadishu.
History of the office.
The first mayor of Mogadishu was <a href="Romeo%20Campani">Romeo Campani</a>, an Italian expatriate who was appointed by General <a href="Rodolfo%20Graziani">Rodolfo Graziani</a>, the <a href="List%20of%20colonial%20governors%20of%20Italian%20Somaliland">Governor of Italian Somaliland</a>. Beginning in 1953 with the appointment of <a href="Cali%20Cumar%20Sheegow">Cali Cumar Sheegow</a>, the office of mayor has been held by native Somalis. After Somalian independence from Italy in 1960, the mayor has been appointed by the <a href="President%20of%20Somalia">President of Somalia</a>.
List of mayors.
Colonial mayors.
The following mayors of Mogadishu were appointed by the <a href="List%20of%20colonial%20governors%20of%20Italian%20Somaliland">Governor</a> of <a href="Italian%20Somaliland">Italian Somaliland</a>. From 1941 to 1949, resulting from <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the British occupied the territory and appointed the mayors, who remained Italians. Beginning in 1953, native Somalis were appointed to the office.
Post-independence mayors.
Since Somalia's independence on 1 July 1960, mayors of Mogadishu have been appointed by the <a href="President%20of%20Somalia">President of Somalia</a>:
Vice mayors.
The mayor of Mogadishu is assisted by a vice mayor or deputy mayor. The current vice mayor is <a href="Iman%20Nur%20Ikar">Iman Nur Ikar</a>.
Living former mayors.
Living former mayors of Mogadishu include: <a href="Hassan%20Mohamed%20Hussein">Hassan Mohamed Hussein</a>, <a href="Hassan%20Abshir%20Farah">Hassan Abshir Farah</a>, <a href="Yusuf%20Hussein%20Jimaale">Yusuf Hussein Jimaale</a>, and <a href="Mohamed%20Nur">Mohamed Nur</a>.
In popular culture.
Towards the end of the <a href="Somali%20Rebellion">Somali Rebellion</a>, President <a href="Siad%20Barre">Siad Barre</a> was sometimes mockingly referred to by many as the "Mayor of Mogadishu," based on the fact that Barre controlled little territory outside the capital. By 1989, when the <a href="United%20Somali%20Congress">United Somali Congress</a> had captured most surrounding towns and villages, this had become a common saying in Somalia, and on 29 September 1990, the British newspaper "<a href="The%20Economist">The Economist</a>" used the phrase in reference to Barre.
During the early 1990s, after the overthrow of the Siad regime and during the <a href="Somali%20famine">Somali famine</a>, <a href="Dan%20Eldon">Dan Eldon</a>, a British photojournalist who covered the famine and conflict, became popular among Mogadishans that he was nicknamed the "Mayor of Mogadishu."
